aws::graph::propositions: # Aviation Accident Report for Bell Helicopter Textron 206L-1 in Grand Canyon
The accident occurred in Grand Canyon, Arizona.
The accident occurred on April 23, 2013, at 14:45 Local time.
The aircraft involved was a Bell Helicopter Textron 206L-1.
The defining event of the accident was a tailstrike.
The flight was conducted under Part 91: General aviation - Instructional.
The accident number was WPR13CA206.
The aircraft registration was N2072M.
The aircraft sustained substantial damage.
There were 2 occupants in the aircraft.
No injuries were reported in the accident.
The flight instructor and pilot receiving instruction were practicing autorotations.
The practice included an autorotation involving a right 180-degree turn.
The flight instructor announced that the throttle was coming on during the maneuver.
The flight instructor announced when full throttle was on.
The pilot started to level the helicopter after the throttle announcements.
The wind shifted to a tailwind during the maneuver.
The tailwind forced the pilot to flare harder than expected.
The tailwind forced the pilot to use more cyclic control than expected.
The flight instructor realized completing a power recovery would result in an overtorque condition.
The flight instructor took over control of the helicopter.
The flight instructor landed the helicopter.
The tailboom was substantially damaged during the landing.
The flight instructor reported no preimpact mechanical malfunctions with the airframe.
The flight instructor reported no preimpact mechanical failures with the airframe.
The flight instructor reported no preimpact mechanical malfunctions with the engine.
The flight instructor reported no preimpact mechanical failures with the engine.
The National Transportation Safety Board determined the probable cause of the accident.
The probable cause was the failure of both pilots to recognize the wind had shifted to a tailwind before entering the flare.
The probable cause included the failure to terminate the practice autorotation.

text:
# Aviation Investigation Final Report

## Location:
Grand Canyon, Arizona

## Date & Time: 
April 23, 2013, 14:45 Local

## Aircraft:
BELL HELICOPTER TEXTRON 206L-1

## Defining Event:
Tailstrike

## Flight Conducted Under:
Part 91: General aviation - Instructional

## Accident Number:
WPR13CA206

## Registration:
N2072M

## Aircraft Damage:
Substantial

## Injuries:
2 None

## Analysis
The flight instructor reported that she and the pilot receiving instruction were practicing autorotations. During an autorotation involving a right 180-degree turn, the flight instructor announced that the throttle was coming on, and then announced when full throttle was on. The pilot then started to level the helicopter. Because the wind had shifted to a tailwind during the maneuver, the pilot was forced to flare harder and use more cyclic control than expected. The flight instructor realized that completing a power recovery from the autorotation was going to result in an overtorque condition, took over control, and landed the helicopter. During the landing, the tailboom was substantially damaged. The flight instructor reported no preimpact mechanical malfunctions or failures with the airframe or engine that would have precluded normal operation.

## Probable Cause and Findings
The National Transportation Safety Board determines the probable cause(s) of this accident to be:The failure of the flight instructor and the pilot receiving instruction to recognize before entering the flare that the wind had shifted to a tailwind and terminate the practice autorotation.

---
